Table 2 Silica added = 0% 13% 20% 26% 33% Total surface area, m2/g 440 413 400 401 400 Meso-pore (100–1000 Ang) surface area, m2/g 395 331 295 241 189 Micro-pore (<50 Ang) surface area, m2/g 21 58 86 143 196 Total pore volume, mL/g 2.73 2.2 1.87 1.49 1.21 Meso-pore (100–1000 Ang) volume, mL/g 2.65 2.11 1.78 1.38 1.07 Micro-pore (<50 Ang) volume, mL/g 0.01 0.02 0.04 0.07 0.10 Reinforcement of Cr/silica catalysts by secondary deposition of silicate oligomers Max P. McDaniel a ⁎ Steve L. Kelly b a Chevron Phillips Chemical Co., Bartlesville, OK 74004, United States Chevron Phillips Chemical Co. Bartlesville OK 74004 United States b Chevron Phillips Chemical Co., Kingwood, TX 77339, United States Chevron Phillips Chemical Co. Kingwood TX 77339 United States ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Ethyl silicate oligomers were impregnated into a generic Phillips Cr/silica catalyst used commercially for ethylene polymerization. After calcination, this treatment results in a secondary deposition of silica into the original silica matrix, which changes the porosity of the catalyst somewhat and strengthens its overall structure. The process can be used as a powerful tool to manipulate polymer properties because the molecular weight of the polymer, the MW distribution, and the amount of long-chain branching (LCB) it contains, were found to be strongly influenced, and with them all aspects of molding behavior. This result provides still more evidence that the physical structure of the Cr/silica catalyst can have major consequences for the polymerization reaction, which shapes the character of the polymer. This method of controlling polymer properties is perhaps more convenient for commercial operations than those described previously. Keywords Ethylene polymerization Phillips catalyst Chromium catalyst Catalyst porosity Long-chain branching Cr/silica Polyethylene Catalyst reinforcement Silicate oligomers 1 Introduction In earlier reports [1–9] it was shown that, quite apart from the chemical composition of the Phillips Cr/silica polymerization catalyst, its physical structure plays a major role in determining its activity in ethylene polymerization, and also (less intuitively) the character of the polyethylene it produces. In particular, the molecular weight of the polymer, the degree of long-chain branching (LCB), and the MW distribution are all influenced by the architecture of the silica support. These molecular features of the polymer then go on to direct its molding behavior and the physical properties of the finished part, making control of the silica structure extremely important to industrial operations. That the activity of Cr/silica should be affected by catalyst architecture is understandable, considering that the growing polymer must fracture the silica support to allow polymer egress. Polymer chains are typically hundreds or thousands of times longer than the diameter of catalyst pores. Although the catalyst may produce thousands of times its weight in polymer during its typical 1-h reaction time, the catalyst pores are filled within the first minute of polymerization. To continue reaction, each silica particle (typically 100 μm) is usually fractured into billions or perhaps trillions of smaller fragments that allow polymer egress. Consequently, anything that weakens the silica structure tends to improve its activity for polymerization. This includes especially the pore volume (PV) of the silica. High PV silicas (>1.5 mL/g) fragment easily to the point where all of the BET surface can participate in the polymerization. This was inferred by comparing the observed activity per square meter of surface to that of non-porous silicas [5,6]. In contrast, silicas of PV less than about 0.8 mL/g usually exhibit little to no polymerization activity. The pores are too strong to permit fragmentation. The dependence of pore strength on PV is explained in terms of the “contact number” of each primary silica particle to its closest neighbors in the sub-structure. Low PV provides a higher number of attached neighbors and thus greater strength. The “weld-strength”, or degree of fusion between one primary silica particle with its neighbors, also determines the overall strength of the silica matrix. This can be controlled through alkaline aging of the silica hydrogel (Oswald ripening), or by thermal sintering or by hydro-thermal treatment (“steaming”). However, while increasing the strength of the silica matrix, such treatments also increase the pore diameter and lower the surface area, because primary particles are fused into a continuous mass resembling Swiss-cheese, as depicted in Scheme 1 . Since the more open pores allow easier escape of polymer chains, the net result of such treatments can often be an improvement in activity (per m2 of surface). Presumably, larger fragments can result from the stronger matrix, but which still permit full egress of polymer [3]. These generalizations describe our experience with silica gels. On the other end of the strength scale, however, are structures in which the sub-particles are not well-connected to each other, such as agglomerations of mico-crystallites, as in some aluminas, or stacks of sheets as occurs in some clays. Such supports are easily fragmented even at very low pore volume [1,3,10–14]. Unlike catalyst activity, the dependence of polymer character on the catalyst’s physical structure is less intuitive, and is still not fully understood. It was shown in earlier work that the PE molecular weight seems to be influenced by the catalyst pore diameter [3,5,15] and that the degree of long-chain branching (LCB) is related to the strength of the silica matrix [3,4,6]. The MW distribution was also shown to vary with catalyst structure. Two peaks were visible, indicating that polymer was formed under two different physical environments. It was proposed that these two peaks represent: 1) polymer made on the exterior of fragments, and 2) polymer “extruded” under pressure through pores from the interior of fragments. Weckhysen et al. [16] has published a particularly interesting micrograph of polymer being “extruded” from the pores of MCM-41. This latter component is much higher in MW and contains significantly more LCB. Its size, relative to the more prominent peak 1, can be varied widely by manipulation of the catalyst architecture, from an almost invisible high-MW tail, to a second equally-sized peak in a bimodal MW distribution. Just why formation and extrusion of polymer from crowded pores would produce higher MW and more LCB is still unclear. It might be related to the difficulty of assuming the necessary precursor position. For example, chain termination by beta-hydride elimination requires that it first assume the “pucker position” to allow agostic beta-H coordination as depicted in Scheme 2 below. This position may be more difficult in a tightly-packed pore. Likewise, the incorporation of macromer to produce LCB requires either retention by coordination [17], or the ability to capture a neighboring chain, which may be easier inside a crowded pore. One could also argue that ethylene concentration is lower inside crowded pores. However, this explanation is not entirely satisfactory because although it would favor LCB formation (which is observed), it would also favor chain termination (which is opposite to observation). One would have to assume that inside crowded pores steric inhibition of chain termination is greater than the effect of low ethylene concentration on MW, which is conceivable. In this paper, we have explored another way to probe the effect of catalyst strength on activity and polymer character. Sintering, steaming or alkaline aging was not used, because these lead to a coalescence of the fine structure, enlargement of pores and loss of surface area. Instead, in the present study the silica matrix was reinforced by a secondary deposition of silica into an existing silica pores. A typical polymerization grade silica was impregnated with various amounts of ethyl silicate oligomers to buttress the network with a secondary coating of silica. Catalysts were then made from these silicas and the resultant activity and polymer behavior was examined. Finally, it is perhaps useful to put this study into a larger general context. Although the present study presents a new way of buttressing the catalyst matrix, it will be shown that its results are nevertheless consistent with these earlier observations from other methods of reinforcement [1–3,5–7,9,16]. A secondary deposition of silica onto the pore walls strengthened the overall catalyst matrix. Polymers made from such catalysts were found to have high MW and LCB content, the result of adding a second, high-MW shoulder to the MW distribution. The results of this form of reinforcement were comparable to, or perhaps more potent than, reinforcement by sintering, “steaming” or alkaline aging. However, this method of buttressing the silica structure is more adaptable to commercial practice, given that PE manufacturers start with pre-formed generic silicas, and cannot fine-tune LCB during plant operation by using aging, sintering or steaming treatments. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts The silica used in this study was manufactured by Philadelphia Quartz Co. under the trade name of MS3050. The oligomers of ethyl silicate were obtained from Evonik Corp. under the trade name Silbond 40 condensed tetraethyl orthosilicate, described as having a molecular weight of around 800. Methanol solutions were made to contain the desired amount of silicate, and enough dissolved basic chromium acetate to equal 1 wt% of the final catalyst. The volume of each solution was set to reach incipient wetness when added to the silica (i.e. about 3.5 mL/g). After impregnation, the silica samples were dried in a vacuum oven at 100 °C overnight. The added silica content was described as silica added as Silbond 40, divided by the total amount of silica from both sources. To activate the final catalyst, approximately 10 g of the dried silica was added to 2-inch diameter quartz tube containing a coarse sintered glass frit (gas distribution plate) at the bottom. An air stream, dried through 13X molecular sieve, was added at the bottom of the tube so that it passed up through the frit and fluidized the catalyst. The air flow was initially set at 0.05 ft/s at 25 °C, and remained constant thereafter. The tube was placed in a furnace and the temperature raised over 1.5 h to 800 °C where it was held for three hours. Afterward the catalyst was flushed with dry nitrogen at 25 °C for 15 min and then captured in a sealed flask. 2.2 Catalyst characterization In a typical experiment, about 0.2 g of sample was degassed in a physisorption tube, using a Micromeritics SmartVacPrep. To prevent portions of the fine particles from boiling up to a region of the sample tube not in the heated zone, the pressure was reduced gradually, and the temperature was increased stepwise. The pressure was initially reduced from ambient to 5 mm Hg, at a controlled rate of 5 mm Hg/s, while holding the samples at 30 °C. After reaching sufficient vacuum [0.09 mm Hg], the temperature was increased to 50 °C, then to 70 °C, then to 90 °C, with each temperature step held for 30 min. The last step held the temperature at 300 °C for 12 h, with the final vacuum reaching a pressure of about 1 milliTorr. After cooling to ambient, the samples were backfilled with nitrogen and analyzed on a Micromeritics TriStar II nitrogen physisorption instrument. Approximately 64 adsorption points were collected to construct an isotherm, and software packages included with the instrument were used to estimate surface areas, total pore volumes, and generate pore size distribution curves. Surface areas were estimated using the BET method [18], from adsorption isotherm points having P/Po values from 0.0 to 0.2. Total pore volume values were calculated from the isotherm point have a P/Po value closest to 0.982. Pore size distributions were generated from desorption isotherm data using the BJH method [19], with thickness curves generated using the Halsey equation [20]. 2.3 Polymerization Ethylene polymerization was conducted in a steel reactor, stirred by a pitched blade at 400–500 rpm. The interior volume of the vessel was 2650 mL. To maintain the temperature accurately, that is, to within 0.5°, coolant water was circulated through an outer jacket. Typically about 50–200 mg of catalyst was added to the reactor under a dry nitrogen blanket, followed by 1200 mL of isobutane liquid. The contents were then heated up to the 105 °C over about three minutes, and ethylene gas was applied to maintain a fixed total pressure of 550 psig (3.79 MPa). The reaction rate was then monitored by intake of new ethylene as the reactor reservoir was being consumed to make solid polymer. After about 60 min the reactor was vented, opened and the dry polyethylene powder was recovered and weighed. The average polymerization rate was then calculated from the weight of polymer recovered and the reaction time. 2.4 Rheology measurements The melt viscosity of polyethylene was determined as function of shear rate at 190 °C. The polymers were first impregnated with 0.1 wt% BHT in acetone, and dried under vacuum. Then slabs were molded under compression at 182 °C, for one minute under low pressure to allow melting, and after that at high pressure for another two minutes. Following cooling under pressure to 25 °C, disks were cut from the molded slab, 0.2 cm thick and 2.54 cm in diameter. A Rheometrics Inc. RMS-800 or ARES rheometer was used to obtain small-strain oscillatory shear determinations under a nitrogen blanket. The oscillation rate was varied to provide shear from 0.03 to 100 radians per second. After the sample disk was loaded into the machine, it was compressed between the plates at 190 °C to 0.16 cm thickness and the overflow was cut away. The entire loading procedure took about eight minutes. The applied strain was usually held at a fixed value while the frequency was varied. Higher viscosity polymers required smaller strains to avoid overworking the transducer. Melt viscosity data was analyzed by use of the Carreau-Yasuda equation to obtain the extrapolated zero-shear viscosity (η0), and the average melt relaxation time (τ) in seconds. The equation also provides an indication of the breadth of the relaxation time distribution, through the parameter CY-a [25]. 2.5 Molecular weight Polyethylene was also analyzed by GPC in order to obtain the various moments of molecular weight, and an indication of the MW breadth. The instrument used was a Waters 150 CV Plus or a Polymer Labs PL220 Gel Permeation Chromatograph. The solvent was 140 °C trichlorobenzene at a 1 mL/min flow rate. BHT (0.5 g/L) was added to prevent polymer degradation. Four PLGel Mixed A columns were used plus a guard column. PE samples were dissolved in trichlorobenzene (0.00186 g/mL at 25 °C) and 220 μL of this solution was typically injected into the machine. Phillips Marlex BHB 5003 polyethylene was selected as a standard reference for broad MW distribution linear PE calibration. The Mark-Houwink equation ([η] = K·Ma) was used where K = 39.5(10–3) mL/g and a = 0.726. 2.6 Rheological analysis of LCB content Estimation of long-chain branching (concentration, location and length) in common HDPE grades is usually problematic. Only branches longer than about 140 carbons (the critical entanglement length for PE) have an effect on the melt rheology [21,22], and consequently this value serves as a useful definition of LCB. By this definition, LCB content cannot be monitored by NMR. Another technique, SEC-MALS (size exclusion chromatography multi-angle light scattering), is sensitive to high levels of LCB, especially when in the high-MW part of the MW distribution. It is even capable of locating LCB in the MW distribution. Unfortunately, SEC-MALS is that the most sensitive indicator of LCB, and LCB in the shorter chains is especially difficult to detect. Nevertheless, SEC-MALS has been used as an additional indication of LCB in several polymers made during this study. In contrast, the effect of long-chain branching, even in trace amounts, on the polymer melt viscosity is profound [23,24]. This is because long branches greatly increase the degree of entanglement which resists melt flow. Thus, the low-shear viscosity is especially amplified by long-chain branching, making it the most sensitive indicator of LCB. The signature is a rise in low-shear melt viscosity that is not accompanied by, or is disproportionate to, a rise in molecular weight. And the most profound effect is observed in the zero-shear melt viscosity (usually designated as η0). Polymers are said to be long-chain branched if they exhibit higher viscosity than would be expected from linear (unbranched) PE of the same molecular weight. The zero-shear viscosity (η0) of linear polyethylene, as with most types of polymer, exhibits a linear relationship with the weight-average molecular weight (MW ) when plotted on a log-log graph. A straight line of slope 3.4 is obtained from such a plot. The existence of long-chain branching is indicated by deviations from this line, often called the “Arnett” line [21,25–27]. Long-chain branching has a more pronounced effect when it is located in the longer chains. This is due to the greater difficulty of disentangling these longer chains during flow. This is called the Janzen-Colby relationship, which is characterized by curved contour lines above the Arnett line for various branching levels [21]. Consequently, these lines can be used to gauge branching amounts in polymers having different MW . Unfortunately, the Janzen-Colby method of LCB detection also comes with some caveats. For example, at extremely low molecular weight, such as MW  = 104, the influence of branching becomes less significant and more difficult to detect. Also, the location of the branches is important in determining an LCB level, having greater significance in the high-MW part of the distribution, so that the LCB value generated from Janzen-Colby is really just an effective average. This also makes the MW breadth important, even for uniformly distributed LCB. A convenient method of correcting for MW breadth, proposed by Yau [27], can be used where polydispersity varies widely. Yau's correction was used in this study to calibrate samples to a known LCB standard. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation Table 1 outlines the experiments conducted as part of this study. Samples of a high porosity polymerization-grade silica, manufactured by Philadelphia Quartz Co. under the trade name of MS3050, were impregnated with various methanolic solutions of condensed oligomers of ethyl silicate to incipient wetness. In this way loadings of 0% to 33% were achieved (wt oligomeric silica over wt total silica). The oligomers of ethyl silicate were obtained from Evonik Corp. under the trade name Silbond 40, described as having a molecular weight of around 800. This would be equivalent to pentamers and hexamers, perhaps having three dimensional, as well as linear, structures. However, the company literature also describes the product as containing a wide distribution of oligomers, including even ethyl silicate monomer as well as a few very large molecules. After the simultaneous impregnation of chromium acetate and silicate oligomers, these samples were dried at 100 °C overnight and then calcined in dry air at 800 °C for three hours to yield an active polymerization catalyst containing 1% Cr(VI). 3.2 Physical characterization The catalyst sample containing no added silica was measured to have a BET surface area of about 440 m2/g and a pore volume of about 2.7 mL/g. Table 1 shows that the addition of silicate oligomers had little effect on the total surface areas of the composite (or “reinforced”) silica samples. However, notice in Table 1 that the pore volume was decreased substantially, down to less than half of the original PV. These two variables are plotted in Fig. 1 as a function of added silica. Also listed in Table 1 is the expected surface area and pore volume if the added silica contributed weight but no area and no volume (other than its skeletal volume, which was subtracted). Notice that the observed surface area is significantly higher than the predicted area, which indicates that the added silica is also contributing some surface area. The calculated area contributions of the added silica are listed in the next line, which are all less than the parent silica. The situation is reversed for the pore volume, because the expected PV is much higher than the observed PV. This indicates that the added silica is probably blocking some of the original pores. Calculation of the PV contributions of the added silica are also shown. They are all negative, indicating that the added silica is actually removing volume, as would be expected from blocked pores. Fig. 2 shows the pore volume and surface area distributions as a function of pore diameter. The plot confirms the previous inferences, and it makes clear that the simple average pore diameter shown is Table 1 is not useful for describing these structures. Notice that the pore volume of the parent silica is almost entirely located in a single meso-pore peak centered about 200 Angstroms. As the silicate oligomers are added, this peak shrinks and shifts slightly to lower diameter. This suggests that while some of the smaller oligomers coated pore walls, a few of the larger oligomers blocked those pores. A small, almost insignificant, amount of pore volume is also introduced in the micro-pore range. This probably represents the porosity of the oligomer silica itself. This micro-porosity is not very significant to the total pore volume, being quite small, and not additive because it merely occupies volume that was originally within the meso-pores. The surface area plot in the lower part of Fig. 2 is also telling. Notice that once again the area of the parent silica is almost entirely concentrated into a single meso-pore peak centered at about 200 Angstroms. A small, almost insignificant amount of surface area is located within micro-pores. As silicate oligomers are added, however, the surface area in the larger pores shrinks with an accompanying small shift to smaller diameter. Again, this indicates wall coating from the smaller oligomers, and some blockage of the larger ones. One can also see a growth in the area inside micro-pores which probably comes from the added silica itself. Unlike its PV contribution, the new area found within micro-pores is indeed additive and thus it has a major effect on the total BET surface area. This explains why the total PV drops in Table 1 whereas the total SA remains almost constant. Notice that, unlike the total SA, the meso-SA parallels the meso-PV as would be expected from this explanation. 3.3 Polymerization activity Table 1 shows how the addition of silicate oligomers lowered the catalyst activity. This might be expected from the strengthening of the silica matrix, which can then better resist its fragmentation by growing polymer chains. However, given the favorable egress expected from the still very large pores, another explanation can be invoked: that the blocked pores make a significant fraction of the surface area unavailable for the reaction. Even calculating the activity based on the original silica alone, as listed in Table 1, still shows a declining activity with added silica, which indicates a declining fraction of the area that contributes to the polymerization reaction. Fig. 3 shows the activity is plotted as a function of silicate oligomer loading. The drop in activity is significant, but not catastrophic. That is, even the most extreme loading did not kill the catalyst, but it did lower the activity to about half of its original value. However, there is another way to view this activity response. Table 2 lists the area and volume contributions from meso- and micro-pores. Notice that a significant contribution to the total area from micro-pores arises as the silica loading increases. This again suggests that the added silica contributes many small pores, which have a significant effect on the surface area, although not on the pore volume. Fig. 4 plots the activity of these samples as a function of the meso-pore area. Notice that it provides a straight line passing through the origin. In other words, the activity is proportional to the meso-pore area, indicating that this is almost the only surface that contributes to the polymerization reaction. The area inside the micro-pores thus does not seem to be a significant contributor to the activity. This would normally be expected, given that a silica having only micro-porosity is usually inactive. 3.4 Molecular weight The various moments of the molecular weight distribution of the polymers are also listed in Table 1 and the weight-average moment (MW ) is plotted in Fig. 3. Notice in Table 1 that MN remains relatively constant, whereas MW and MZ , both more sensitive to the longer chains, increase dramatically. Adding silicate oligomers drove up the molecular weight of the polymer. Rising MW usually accompanies a shrinking pore size and pore volume [3–5]. However, compared to earlier experiments, the drop in meso-pore diameter seems small for such a large rise in MW . However, the MW change is reasonable for the change in meso-pore volume. This may reflect the reinforcement of the meso-pores, which inhibits fragmentation, causing larger fragments and more polymer to be made inside pores. Another possibility is that the increasing MW reflects a small contribution from the micro-pores, which although contributing little to the total activity, might still make a significant contribution to the molecular weight. However, this does not seem likely in view of the large change in MW , which would require a significant high-MW contribution. The MW distributions, which are discussed below, provide further confirmation of this point. Table 1 also lists the melt index [28] of these polymers as measured using a 2.16 kg weight and also using 21.6 kg weight (also called the high-load melt index, or HLMI). This is a simple viscosity measurement used widely in commercial operations and sales. It measures the amount of polymer extruded through a standard orifice at 190 °C in 10 min under a standard load. It is used to reflect the MW of the polymer, being inversely related to the 3.4 power of MW . This comes with caveats, however, namely that the MW distribution and LCB content remain fairly constant within a comparison series of polymers. The relationship holds fairly well within the family of polymers in Table 1, at least until the most heavily loaded sample (33% added silica). Thus, the addition of silicate oligomers causes the MI and HLMI to drop, as expected from earlier experiments in which the pore volume or pore diameter were lowered in other ways. 3.5 Long chain branching In previous work LCB could usually be correlated with the strength of the catalyst matrix [6], and the data set in Table 1 appears to be no exception. The addition of silicate oligomers caused the amount of LCB found in the polymer to rise, as shown in Table 1 and plotted in Fig. 3. This value of LCB was determined by using the Janzen-Colby rheological method [21], as shown in Fig. 5 . Because long-chain branches become entangled with other chains, they have a profound effect on the low-shear melt viscosity and their presence can be detected and quantified using this relationship even at very low concentrations. The ultimate low-shear measurement is the zero-shear melt viscosity, which is extrapolated from a plot of viscosity at 190 °C versus shear rate, using the Carreau-Yasuda equation [29]. The zero-shear viscosity of a linear polymer is known to be related to its weight-average moment of molecular weight (MW ) raised to the 3.4 power. On a log-log plot, linear polymers (no LCB) produce a straight line having a slope of 3.4. The presence of LCB, however, raises the viscosity off the line (at least initially) and the more LCB present the higher the viscosity. However, the melt viscosity is also a function of MW , and Janzen and Colby derived this relationship [21]. Using the Janzen-Colby equation affords a simple approximation of the amount of LCB present in a polymer of any molecular weight if the zero-shear viscosity and MW are known. Fig. 5 shows a Janzen-Colby plot for the polymers in Table 1. The log of the zero-shear viscosity is plotted against the log of MW . The lower line, having a slope of 3.4, is the reference for linear polymers (0 LCB). The middle line shows the zero-shear viscosity expected for polymers having 1 long-chain branch per million carbons, and the top line shows it for polymers having 10 LCBs per million carbons. Notice that the data points representing the experimental polymers start out (that is at 0% silicate oligomer loading) below the 1 LCB line, but they rise (even though MW is also rising) to about 5 LCB (i.e. between the 1 and 10 LCB reference lines) for the most heavily loaded catalyst. Thus, Janzen-Colby provides a very simple method of LCB measurement. Because it depends on rheological measurements, it is extremely sensitive to LCB. However, it provides only an average or effective LCB content. It cannot be used to locate LCB within the MW distribution, as the less sensitive SEC-MALS (size exclusion chromatography, multi-angle light scattering) does [30]. NMR cannot be used for LCB measurement because it cannot discriminate between short branches and long-chain branches (i.e. longer than the critical entanglement length of ∼140 carbons). The reason for the rise in LCB with secondary silica deposition could relate back to one or both of the explanations mentioned above. First, the silica is becoming increasingly reinforced by wall coatings and perhaps filling of primary particle contact points, which would make the matrix more resistant to fragmentation. The resultant larger fragments could mean that more polymer is made inside pores, which as noted above, provide more LCB. Second, the surface area inside micro-pores also increases with silica loading, and could also be contributing a small amount of highly branched polymer, but not enough to affect the activity. 3.6 Molecular weight distribution The molecular weight distributions of these polymers are shown in Fig. 6 , which shows exactly how the shift to higher MW occurred for the MW and MZ moments. Instead of an overall shift of the whole MW distribution, a high-MW shoulder is instead added with increasing loading of the silicate oligomers. This also explains the broadening of the MW breadth that was listed in Table 1. The addition of a high-MW shoulder, or even a full second peak, has been seen before in connection with reinforcement of the silica matrix by Oswald ripening [3,5]. Apparently, this type of reinforcement, by secondary deposition of silica into the pores, has the same result. This bimodal character is thought to be due to the formation of polymer in two distinct chemical/physical environments. The emerging high-MW peak was proposed to be polymer made and extruded from pores of catalyst fragments, whereas the main peak was thought to be the result of polymerization on the exterior of fragments. One can see in Fig. 6 that the shoulder makes up a significant fraction of the total weight of the polymer. This is why the shoulder is probably not the result of micro-pores. It would inconsistent with Fig. 4, which indicated little contribution by micro-pores to the overall activity. Furthermore, the same bimodal behavior was also observed from catalysts subjected to Oswald ripening [3,4], which does not create any micro-porosity. The new higher-MW shoulder that develops from matrix reinforcement, whether in this study by secondary silica deposition, or in earlier studies using alkaline aging, sintering or steaming [3,4,7], contains the majority of the observed LCB, which is evident in SEC-MALS measurements [7]. Single-site catalysts concentrate LCB into the highest MW chains, a bias resulting from the fact that the act of adding a long-chain branch greatly increases the MW of that chain. However, the situation is different for Phillips Cr/silica catalysts. SEC-MALS shows that LCB is concentrated into the mid-MW range, a result of having a wide diversity of site types, which are distinguished from each other by chemical differences on the silica surface. Reinforcement of the silica matrix does not change that site distribution, and thus the resulting LCB pattern. Instead, it amplifies and shifts the LCB distribution to higher MW, which is contained within the new high-MW shoulder (as shown in Fig. 5 of ref. [7]). 4 Conclusions It has been shown that Cr/silica catalyst can be modified by impregnation of silicate oligomers directly into its pores. After the usual calcination or “activation” of the catalyst, the resultant modified Cr/silica is chemically identical to its parent, with a similar surface concentration of chromium. Nevertheless it now produces completely different polymer, having significantly higher molecular weight and higher degree of long-chain branching. This has profound commercial consequences for polymer flow and elasticity, which govern all molding behavior. And the final physical properties of the molded article can also be influenced, either directly, or indirectly through molding responses. Therefore, these and many other such polymer behaviors are ultimately traced back to the structure of the Cr/silica catalyst. Lastly, although the present study presents a new way of buttressing the catalyst matrix, its results are nevertheless consistent with these earlier observations from other methods of increasing particle strength [1–3,5–7,9,16]. coredata.dc:description: Ethyl silicate oligomers were impregnated into a generic Phillips Cr/silica catalyst used commercially for ethylene polymerization. After calcination, this treatment results in a secondary deposition of silica into the original silica matrix, which changes the porosity of the catalyst somewhat and strengthens its overall structure. The process can be used as a powerful tool to manipulate polymer properties because the molecular weight of the polymer, the MW distribution, and the amount of long-chain branching (LCB) it contains, were found to be strongly influenced, and with them all aspects of molding behavior. This result provides still more evidence that the physical structure of the Cr/silica catalyst can have major consequences for the polymerization reaction, which shapes the character of the polymer. This method of controlling polymer properties is perhaps more convenient for commercial operations than those described previously.
coredata.dc:title: Reinforcement of Cr/silica catalysts by secondary deposition of silicate oligomers
